segments.text: Dispatch, this is Unit 27, en route to Foothills ER with a trauma patient, male, approximately thirty-two years old. High-speed head-on collision with a transport truck. Found restrained in driver’s seat, airbags deployed.
Patient semi-conscious, GCS ten, responds to painful stimuli only. Airway patent but gurgling respirations noted — suctioning performed on scene.
Cervical collar applied, full spinal precautions maintained. Oxygen via non-rebreather mask at fifteen liters per minute. Initial SpO₂ eighty-nine, now ninety-four.
Blood pressure eighty-eight over fifty-six, heart rate one-thirty-two, respirations twenty-six, skin pale and diaphoretic. Abdomen firm, distended — possible internal bleeding.
Two large-bore IVs established — sixteen gauge left antecubital, eighteen gauge right hand. Administered five hundred milliliters normal saline bolus, fluids running wide open.
Minor scalp wound and superficial laceration to right forearm. Bleeding controlled with direct pressure and dressing.
Chest assessment — equal breath sounds, slightly diminished on left. No tracheal deviation or JVD. Possible pulmonary contusion.
Pelvis unstable on compression, applied pelvic binder. No movement in lower limbs, possible spinal involvement.
Two milligrams morphine given slow IV push for pain, no adverse reaction observed. Patient drifting in and out of consciousness, GCS now eight.
Preparing for rapid transport. Current vitals: heart rate one-twenty-eight, blood pressure eighty-four over fifty-two, SpO₂ ninety-three on oxygen, respirations twenty-four. ETA nine minutes.

Foothills ER, this is Unit 27 inbound with one critical trauma. Thirty-two-year-old male, high-speed MVC, hypotensive, possible internal bleed and pelvic fracture. Two IVs established, fluids running, morphine administered, airway maintained. ETA nine minutes.
Copy that, continue fluids, monitor airway, notify if vitals deteriorate.
Blood pressure dropping — now seventy-eight over fifty, heart rate one-thirty-six. Switching to pressure infusion. Preparing for airway intervention if needed.
Patient cyanotic, SpO₂ eighty-eight. Beginning assisted ventilations with BVM. Suctioning again — significant blood in oropharynx.
Airway adjunct inserted, oropharyngeal airway in place. Continuing bag-valve-mask ventilations. Chest rise present but shallow. Pressure improving slightly — eighty-two over fifty-four.
Maintain airway support. We’re five minutes out. Notify trauma bay — probable massive transfusion required.
Monitoring en route. Abdomen remains rigid, no new external bleeding. IV fluids wide open.

Final report: thirty-two-year-old male, polytrauma. Suspected internal hemorrhage, pelvic instability, possible spinal injury. Airway supported with OPA and BVM. Received five hundred milliliters normal saline and two milligrams morphine IV. Current vitals — BP eighty-two over fifty-four, HR one-thirty, assisted respirations at eighteen per minute, SpO₂ ninety-one. ETA two minutes.
Copy that, Foothills ER ready for immediate handoff.
Roger, arriving now.
